item.title: Oscar Prediction
item.description:
My prediction of 2015 Oscar winners in eleven major categories:

Best Picture

Birdman

Every shot and scene of this movie has "Oscar" written on it. It's got such an ambitious vision and executes it so flawlessly. It strikes an overall balance of universally resonating story (a hero's journey of redemption), excellent acting all around (Keaton, Norton, Stone), perfect pace (done in one continuous shot), and creativity (mix of magical surrealism).

Best Director

Richard Linklater

Probably no director in the history of movies is as ambitious as Linklater when he undertook the journey of making Boyhood in 2002. It's an epic journey that embodies everything movie is supposed to be, back to its original root. What he's accomplished, is extremely inspiring and admirable. The story can probably connect to every American family at different levels. It would have been easy for Linklater to over-dramatize the story or over-stretch characters' conflict, like what happened to American Sniper, but he didn't. This award is long overdue for Linklater.

Best Actor in a Leading Role

Michael Keaton

This category is the most competitive one tonight, as every nominee delivers sizzling performance. By pure acting feat, Redmayne, Keaton, Cumberbatch, Carell, Cooper can all go home with this award credibly. That said, Keaton has been a soldier in this industry and basically acts his heart out with his own life. Everybody other nominee still has their shot at Oscar but this is probably the last chance for Keaton. He deserves this.

Best Actress in a Leading Role

Julian Moore

The competition is over. Moore has swept all the leading actress awards so far leading up to Oscar. She's been doing great work consistently over the years and an Oscar nod is long overdue for her.

Best Actor in a Supporting Role

J.K.Simmons

Whiplash is basically the story of J.K.Simmons winning his Oscar. He carried the entire movie on his shoulders and mesmerize audience with every scene he's in. Unbelievable performance.

Best Actress in a Supporting Role

Patricia Arquette

There are few actresses who are willing to allow a director to capture her aging process over twelve years span. Arquette did that and gave a heartfelt performance. Her courage and commitment alone should win her this Oscar.

Best Original Screenplay

Wes Anderson

Come on, it's time to give an Oscar to Anderson. The Grand Budapest Hotel is well liked across the board but will not stand a chance with Boyhood and Birdman in the top categories. The least the Academy can do is to recognize Adnerson's writing.

Best Adapted Screenplay

American Sniper

I'm not a big fan of the movie. It's a fine movie with good direction and acting, but I'm not sure it's that good to be an Oscar Best Picture contender. American Sniper should win something at least. Maybe this is the one.

Best Cinematography

Birdman

One continuous shot for the entire movie - that's enough to trump all other contenders.

Best Production Design

The Grand Budapest Hotel

The production design is central to the overall effect of The Grand Budapest Hotel and Anderson should be recognized for his idiosyncratic cinematic vision.

Best Film Edit

Boyhood

It's impossible to even imagine the magnitude of the amount of work and the level of difficulty of editing a movie over twelve years. Boyhood will win.

item.title: Asian Movies Recommendations for My American Friends
item.description:
Since I get asked this question a lot, here's my current list. It's not meant to be an exhaustive list, just a collection of my personal favorites that I think my American friends may enjoy as well in recent years.

  1. Let the Bullets Fly, China, 2010, IMDB 7.2, directed by Wen Jiang, action/thriller

    China's answer to Christopher Nolan's Inception, only better. It's directed by Wen Jiang, China (mainland)'s most talented film director, who left Yimou Zhang and Xiaogang Feng in dust with this period epic. Being an entertaining roller-coaster ride, it's also highly complex with profound and subtle references that challenge the most intellectual ones in Chinese audience. For non-Chinese, it'll be impossible to pick up the cultural and historical references and the many sub-plots, but you should still watch it just so that you can claim you've watched the one movie that absolutely defines the pinnacle of Chinese (mainland) film achievement.

    I wish I could list more Mainland China movies on this list, but there ain't too many to speak about yet. The market has been growing like a rocket, which is a different matter.

  2. Kung Fu Hustle, Hong Kong, 2004, IMDB 7.8, directed by Stephen Chow, kungfu action

    Stephen Chow is widely regarded as all-time best and most gifted Chinese film maker there has been. My generation grew up with his movies and quotes. Unfortunately he's also extremely underrated as a movie director and actor, despite his already massive commercial and critical success. It's similar to how Prince is so underrated as a gifted guitar shredder and musician in general despite of being already a superstar of superstars.

    Kung Fu Hustle displayed Chow's undeniable talent in full glory. It's a wonder to behold.

  3. A Chinese Odyssey Part One: Pandora's Box, 1995, IMDB 7.9; A Chinese Odyssey Part Two: Cinderella, 1995, IMDB 8.1, Hong Kong, directed by Jeffrey Lau, fantasy/romantic action

    Do not be fooled by the cheesy posters on IMDB. This is the No.1 Chinese cult movie of all-time that singled-handedly defined my entire generation of those born in the 70s in China. 1995 became the most magical year in movie history not because of Tarantino's Pulp Fiction, but because of Lau/Chow's A Chinese Odyssey (released in two parts in the same year). If you think Tarantino's quotes in Pulp Fiction or Kar Wai Wong's quotes in Ashes of Time are uber-cool, they don't come even close to the ones in this movie.

    When this movie took over Mainland China's colleges by storm in the form of pirated VCDs in 1995-1996, it was considered mainstream and norm among college students to read and recite its entire script, line by line. Other than Casablanca (1942), I don't know of any other movie that has achieved such a legendary God-like status among such a broad audience. Its spectacular commercial failure in 1995 in Hong Kong only proved how visionary Lau/Chow were and how much they were ahead of their time. While everybody thought they were making another summer pop-corn comedy flick, they created an avant-garde postmodernism masterpiece with an epic time-travel love story that is still being talked about and missed by Chinese to this date.

    For non-Chinese, unfortunately it'll be a given that you will have no clue of what this movie is so great about. Most Chinese could not understand it when it first came out. No translation would do justice to the original quotes, like many other Stephen Chow movies, which is really a shame.

  4. Election, Hong Kong, 2005, IMDB 7.1, Triad Election, Hong Kong, IMDB 7.4, both directed by Johnnie To, gangster action

    It's actually a two-part movie. Simply put, this is the Godfather 1 & 2 in Hong Kong, in the setting that defines Hong Kong cinematic scene (triad society), with outstanding performance by an amazing cast.

    The movie is epic, profound, brutal, and very, very poetic.

  5. Kill Zone - S.P.L., Hong Kong, 2005, IMDB 7.2, directed by Wilson Yip, kungfu gangster action

    Donnie Yen is unquestionably the No.1 kungfu star that has filled the void left behind by Jackie Chan and Jet Li. Especially after Ip Man (2008), even the most die-hard fans of Chan and Li would have to agree that Yen has convincingly surpassed them as the best Chinese kungfu star.

    Yen has been making kungfu films for many years, but it was 2005's SPL that firmly established him as the superstar of the current generation. It featured an alley-fighting sequence that is generally considered the best one-on-one fighting scene of all time (yes you heard me right). It also featured a landmark duel between Yen and the great Sammo Hung Kam-Bo at the climax.

  6. Monga, Taiwan, 2010, IMDB 7.0, directed by Doze Niu, gangster action/thriller

    Gangster movies is a thing for Hong Kong, and Taiwan is never known for this genre. Doze's Monga in 2010 changed all that. This movie catapulted him from a C-list actor to A-list director, an amazing feat that was just as epic as Robert Downey Jr's comeback in Iron Man.

  7. The Host, South Korea, 2006, IMDB 7.0, directed by Joon-ho Bong, monster horror

    While Hollywood's monster movie genre has been largely following the script written by Spielberg since the 90s, Joon-ho Bong presented some kind of monster movie that was quite a different and refreshing treat. The opening sequence is simply breath-taking.

    The movie is really about family love and how ordinary people overcome insurmountable obstacles to redeem themselves - a classic hero's journey story. It featured versatile and talented Kang-ho Song, the best Asian actor of this generation, in my opinion (yes, better than Tony Leung from Hong Kong).

  8. Memories of Murder, South Korea, 2003, IMDB 8.1, directed by Joon-ho Bong, crime thriller

    It's often considered the best movie there has been from South Korea. South Korea's movies, collectively have been the best out of Asia in the last ten years. That's enough of a reason to check this one out.

    Kang-ho Song starred, of course.

  9. Sex Is Zero, South Korea, 2002, IMDB 6.8, directed by Je-gyun Yun, high-school comedy

    American Pie, South Korea version, but much better. It is outrageously funny. However, be prepared for wild mood shift.

  10. Fuyajo, Japan, 1998, IMDB 7.2, directed by Chi-Ngai Lee, gangster thriller

    This list would not be complete without mentioning Japanese movies. However, I just haven't watched enough Japanese movies in recent years to speak intelligently here - shame on me. Japanese movie deserves to be in the league of its own.

    Very few people have watched or heard about Fuyajo, not to mention understanding its extremely convoluting plot. It didn't help that five languages were frequently spoken throughout the movie, despite of this being a Japanese production. I have been a great admirer of this movie for many years. It's a hidden gem that pierces through the deepest corner of Tokyo, in a very sad love story.

    This is the best movie by Takeshi Kaneshiro. The movie was almost tailor-made to leverage his multi-cultural backgrounds. Kaneshiro, for those of you who do not know, is universally hailed as the most handsome male Asian star for the past 15-20 years. Both men and women are crazy for him.

item.title: 杨记美食四月篇
item.description:
在2014年3月初的某一天，我正在经受Pressed Juice三天program的煎熬。饥肠辘辘之间，心有顿悟，觉得自己动手，丰衣足食。于是，我就在下面的几周里，做了几盘小菜。

照烧鸡腿 一开始想了半天“照烧”是什么东西？后来在网上一查恍然大悟，就是teriyaki啊！这道菜的关键是照烧汁。我有用一点从超市买的Teriyaki Sauce，但因为量不够了，就自己按照生抽：料酒：蜂蜜 = 3：3：1的比例另外配置了一些。一开始除去鸡腿骨稍有麻烦，有把好使的剪刀会省很多力。鸡腿的腌制花了一个多小时，但我觉得时间还不够，下次得更加提前开始腌制。最后的味道稍微咸了点儿。

哨子面 大家都喜欢吃，很少有人喜欢做，因为配料太麻烦了。还好，越麻烦的菜，我越喜欢做。这道菜需要切很多菜，还好我继承了妈妈的基因，擅长切菜。自己做的哨子面，原料都是organic的，不含任何味精，味道比餐馆里的好很多。

溜肥肠 大概是这季里难度最高的一道菜，有两个技术门槛。第一是把肠子洗干净；第二是把肠子煮熟。第一次洗肠子，不大看得出来哪些是肥肉，哪些是淋巴，只能一边洗一边摸索。用水来不停地冲洗就能把淋巴/肥肉比较容易地分离出来了。豆果网上的各种溜肥肠菜谱都不能很清楚地说明白到底需要煮多长时间，后来我从百度上搜索才发现需要煮一个小时之久！难怪后来吃的时候觉得嚼得不够烂。

蒜炒上海青 按照爸爸的嘱咐，盐要在最后快要起锅的时候再放 - 否则蔬菜出水太早。果然很灵验，上海青青翠欲滴。不过，为什么这道菜叫上海青，而不是武昌青呢？

炝炒土豆丝 我从小就喜欢吃土豆丝。小时候吃的土豆丝，包括后来我在新加坡做的土豆丝，都比较重口味。现在口味清淡了，改作炝炒土豆丝。很容易，土豆丝切细就可以了。

鱼香肉丝 本季最为惊艳的作品，做了两次，都很成功。也是需要切无数的菜，但很值得，看来会成为杨记的保留主菜之一了。

排骨萝卜汤 本季早期作品，具体的做法已经不可考，反正结果不错。

item.title: A Day In A Sloan's Life
item.description:
I have done a lot of presentations in my life, from participating in an English speech contest for high-school students broadcast live on China's national television (CCTV) at age 15, to delivering a company presentation on China's largest VC/PE firm - CDH's annual LP conference in Venetian, Macau. This "A Day In A Sloan's Life" presentation, as a "ramp" speech delivered to the Sloan Fellows of 2014 and Sloan Fellows of 2013 in CEMEX Auditorium in Stanford Graduate Business School on April 14, 2013, during Sloan's April Orientation, left everything before it in dust. It was finished right at the very last second before class president John Barton finished his introduction of me.

The music is Robert Miles' Children (Dream Version). The pictures came from a variety of sources, including Her Extraordinaire Ede Tamkivi and Jacqueline Wu, two best photographers of our class.

This is the way I've always imagined our story should be told.

item.title: COASSF#49 - Chinese New Year Party
item.description:
On February 8, 2013, I emceed Sloan's Chinese New Year Party, which made history by becoming the most attended self-organized Sloan event with roughly 180 people (120 adults + 60 kids), in true Chinese fashion. We squeezed out every inch in Havana Room but still could not find enough chairs/tables for all the Sloans and the partners. The party followed a format that was familiar to every Mainland Chinese - a gala filled with delicious food, baijiu (Chinese white wine, very hard-core liquor) , stage performances, and variety shows. Not only it was a banquet of food and drink, but also it was a total cultural immersion of three hours in which I walked through five parts of some interesting elements of Chinese culture.

Part I - The Opening Teaser (you are supposed to be scared)

Part II - Story of Chinese Food

Part III - Story of Chinese New Year

Party IV - Story of Year of Snake

Part V - Story of Chinese Characters

Finally, you know you are on a Chinese New Year party when:

  1. You're drowned in an ocean of people

  2. Food keeps flowing

  3. People are getting high on baijiu

  4. The dumplings are delicious!

  5. It's very noisy

  6. Extremely chaotic all around - always something breaking somewhere

  7. Most people dressed in red

  8. Continuous on-stage shows and performances

  9. Some MC is speaking tirelessly on stage, while most people tune in half-heartedly and focus on eating dumplings

  10. The party ends with a heartwarming song (either Unforgettable Tonight, or The Moon Speaks For My Heart)

For the Stanford GSB Sloan Fellow Chinese New Year Party on this Friday, Feb 08，2013. The songs are picked for:

  1. Their festive and party spirit;

  3. Their ability to represent certain distinctive genres of Chinese music;
  4. Their coverage of the key Chinese regions such as Hong Kong, Taiwan, Southeast Asia, and Mainland. The audience for this party consists of 80 Sloan Fellows with their partners/children that come from 30+ countries all over the world with age ranging from 30 - 45 （roughly）.

item.description:
光阴荏苒，如白驹过隙。混迹于新浪微博，已近三年。我在新浪微博上渡过的最欢乐的时光，是在好友私密群“浪博一派”里。关于浪博一派的由来，请见2010年9月30日的拙文《相忘于浪博》。近日腾讯微信走势凌厉，大有改朝换代，取代新浪微博之势。既感叹于新浪微博的日暮西山，又担忧于浪博微群的信息存档，遂开始整理浪博史料，以资后人捧腹。细读浪博旧文，上面叙着堕落腐败之乡，风花雪月之事，以及家庭琐事，闺阁闲情，诗词谜语，倒还全备。群公告中又有一偈云：

无才可去送敲钟，

偶入浪博若许年。

此系筑梦千重事，

请谁记去作传奇？

在那海的那边海的这边有一群七零灵，她们冰雪又聪颖，他们才高又热情。他们互敬互爱你吹我捧结盟成一派，她们跋山涉水一起来腐败。欧\~犀利的浪博女，欧\~自恋的浪博男，他们天南海北无所不侃刷屏到天明，她们勇敢美丽活出最绚丽！

The dance "Gangnam Style“ was performed by 26 Sloan Students from Stanford University Graduate School of Business, for the NCAA Men's Basketball Game Stanford vs Cal State on Nov 12, 2012 (Stanford won, of course).

None of us expected this to happen when we applied for Stanford University's GSB Sloan Program. After our highly successful flash mob on Oct 12 in GSB Town & Square, I was exhausted and thought that was it, I would hear Psy's Gangnam Style no more. Then an invitation came, asking us to perform the same dance/song for Stanford University's varsity teams, such as Men's Basketball, Women's Basketball, and Women's Volleyball. We thought, wow, we're becoming cheerleaders for Stanford in televised NCAA games! As a movie junkie who has soaked up too much Hollywood trash over the past two decades, I was keenly aware how competitive it was to become a cheerleader in a top university like Stanford. This would triumph all other accomplishments we could possibly amass in the Sloan program; this would mark the pinnacle of our alternative career track in entertainment; this was an offer we could not refuse; and the rest, was history.

Saluting to all the Sloan dancers who were part of this historical moment for GSB. Thank you for standing by your commitment and taking time out of your crazy GSB schedule to endure so many hours of sweaty dance training sessions.

item.description:
纵横博海，近日惊见大洋彼岸崛起一股博坛新势力。其特立独行的博风，矫矫不群的博姿，俾倪群豪的博技，和那剪不断理还乱的博态，让人拍案惊奇，舌挢不下。古人云，相濡以沫，不如相忘于江湖。俺云，相聊以gtalk，不如相忘于浪博。此新势力有几大特点：

  1. 集团化作战能力超强，群起而围之，群围而侃之，群侃而博之，不把无辜围观脖子侃晕誓不停博。集团军所过之处，严格执行“雁过拔毛，涸泽而渔，坚壁清野”的政策。被mark上的博主往往不经意之间就发现自己已经在白驹过隙的瞬间被秒@了数十次。自己幼年的心理阴影，潜藏多年的欲望，已经被各种眼花缭乱的科学理论彻底解构，鉴定完毕，无所遁形。

  2. 水银泻地般的逻辑分析能力，百川纳海般的社科八卦知识，和天花乱坠般的雄辩诡辩狡辩技巧，构成火力极其恐怖的交叉攻击网络。低RP博主若不慎踏入其熠熠如满天繁星的视线，绝对粉身碎骨，百死莫赎。有时无博可侃，则互相对攻嬉戏，随时练博备战，保持犀利哥般的博风，方舟子般的斗志，和超级赛亚人3般的热血状态。

  3. 人人互粉，凝聚力极高。秉承骷髅党的精英情怀，关注人群数量少而精，绝不关注智商低于150的面目可憎之人（黝黑的可爱胖子除外）。每人严格监控自己粉丝数量，宁缺勿滥。鄙视粉丝三位数的媚俗之辈。

item.title: 歌坛人士的七大境界以及八大忌讳
item.description:
混迹歌坛多年，总结出歌坛人士的七大境界：

  • 第一境界：兵马俑型。基本不会唱任何歌，完全不愿意参加歌局，即使去了也完全不可能high起来。对唱歌或者公共场合的噪音有与生俱来或者不可言喻的反感。这种类型多见于常年在海外生活（特别是美国这种农村），只能通过偶尔浏览广大群众喜闻乐见的文学城（或者它的升级版未名空间）来获得微不足道的国内娱乐信息的人群中。

  • 第二境界：闷骚型。绝对不会主动去唱歌，被人邀请时往往说“我真的什么都不会”，或者“我是不唱歌的，就听听”。但酒过七八巡后，潜伏多年的欲望终于爆发，借着酒劲开始飚二三十年前的流行金曲，而且往往不鸣则已，一鸣惊人，唱个没完。当然，能否在调子上是另外一回事了。对于这种同志，我们要采取宽容理解支持拥护的态度，让他/她一次爽个够。毕竟，重在参与。

  • 第三境界：爱好型。歌局的积极参与者。比较喜欢唱歌，能唱不少歌。对自己熟悉的，练过的歌唱得有模有样。但一旦对歌曲不熟，水平马上出现较大落差。以自己的能力能否驾驭作为歌曲选择的标准。在正态分布的曲线中，这是中部的60-70%。

  • 第四境界：麦霸型。能唱巨多的流行曲目。往往有不错的嗓子，高音低音都能玩一把，而且体力好，连续唱4–5个小时不在话下。唱歌没有太多的主观选择，基本上以量取胜。这个级别的人，音基本都能唱准，但往往缺乏歌曲里所应有的感觉，既俗称“soul”的那种微妙的feeling。

  • 第五境界：少林派。一开嗓，满座皆惊：OMG，高手，传说中的高手出场了！有强烈的自我表现欲和歌唱欲，往往主动组织歌局。随意娴熟演绎二三百首歌不在话下。经常能cover某些性格/天王歌手的所有曲目。对自己仰慕的歌手风格着力模仿，往往形神兼备，以假乱真，同时陷入严重的自我陶醉的追星状态中，以听到“你唱得真像XXX”为荣。尚未能走出明星的shadow，尚未能创立自己的个人风格。

  • 第六境界：竹林派。关注的已经不再是唱歌的技巧和数量（这是不言而喻的），开始着意培养自己的个人风格，以听到”你唱得真像XXX"为耻（或者，你的名字真像XX歌手）。对歌曲的选择以歌局的气氛，参与者的背景和状态为主，更多关注观众们想听什么，而不是自己能唱什么（因为，很简单，什么都能唱）。经常泡在录音棚里自己录歌，经常颠覆成名歌手的名作，以分享自己的音乐为乐。

  • 第七境界：逍遥派。钱柜，录音棚都已经不能满足自己的需要，开始产生强烈的欲望要组建自己的乐队，这样才可以实现对歌曲的重新编曲，对风格，节奏的彻底颠覆，让歌曲，配乐都能完全配合自己的嗓音特点。对大多数普通听众的赞誉已经麻木，但热切需要志同道合者（简称世外大高手）的共鸣和认可。

在歌局上一般需要注意的八大行业潜规则：

  1. 忌抢麦

    此乃歌局第一大忌。在没有别人的同意前，不要贸然跟人合唱，尤其是歌局开始阶段每个人的开场曲目，尤其是跟对方在歌局上没有经过起码十场以上水乳交融的磨合期。对自己稍有追求的歌手，在一个比较陌生的歌局里的前三首歌都会祭出属于“震场”级别的曲目，make his/her presence felt。这个时候不知天高地厚地去跟人合唱，第一显得不懂规矩很粗鲁，第二显得，嗯，很二。

    跟“抢麦“很接近但性质完全不同的是“接麦”，即在别人力不从心的时候托对方一把，譬如摇滚歌曲的高潮或者阶段，往往一个人唱缺乏气氛而且欠缺山呼海啸的效果。这个时候以和声的角度来托朋友一把是说得过去的，譬如零点乐队的《爱不爱我》或者项亚蕻的《伤》。另外一个可以合理接麦的地方是和声，譬如凤凰传奇《自由飞翔》里男生部的rap和Beyond《海阔天空》里的“谁没在变“。

  2. 忌胡乱为别人点歌

    有人喜欢在歌局开始前在屏幕上胡乱点上一堆时下流行的歌曲，然后憨憨地说，这些歌肯定有人会唱！嗯，never do that。 一个稍微有水准的歌局，肯定有高手在场可以无间歇唱上4-5个小时，不要越俎代庖，一厢情愿地去点那些口水歌。是的，这些歌肯定有人会唱，but 会唱 is NOT the point。唱歌是一个有选择，有品味，有风格的三有雅事，标准不可放低。

  3. 忌连续唱超过三首歌

    点歌的时候就要注意，不要连续点一长串自己的歌，考虑一下别人的感受。如果阴差阳错发现自己连续唱了好几首歌（三首），主动地把自己的下一首歌排后甚至放弃。不就是一首歌而已嘛，唱得再好也比不上陈奕迅。

  4. 忌在别人演绎抒情曲目时高声聊天

    有些歌手已经步入了上述的第五境界，对演唱环境和观众有比较挑剔的要求。某些歌曲显然需要比较安静的环境和专心的听众（譬如张国荣的《明星》和陈奕迅的《活着多好》）。当歌手进入心神俱醉，物我两忘的moment，大家最好配合一下气氛。

  5. 忌很晚到场。

    KTV的经济是一个fixed cost为主的模式，一个房间的费用，跟时间，房间大小，酒水消费水平有关，跟超过最低数量的party人数以上的额外的人数的相关度很低。如果来得晚的话（譬如，晚两个小时以上），会让party主人在分账时的计算变得很麻烦。

  6. 忌唱儿歌，或者过量的民歌（王洛宾的歌除外）

    没人对这些歌感兴趣，不管你唱得多好。They just ain't cool。

  7. 忌唱古巨基的《劲歌金曲1》，《劲歌金曲2》，林子祥的《十分十二吋》，《街头霸王榜》

    这些歌太长了，耗费太多公共时间，只有在party开始人数不齐需要暖场时才应该考虑它们。

  8. 忌过量的此恨绵绵无绝期的不适合K厅的曲目

    不是所有的歌曲都适合K厅，过于舒缓，过于冷门，过于凝重的歌曲自己在K歌达人/唱吧上唱唱就可以了，譬如黄小琥和张悬的某些歌。简而言之，K厅里的歌，以助兴为主，卖艺为辅，别一不小心成为冷场王。

item.title: 枪炮与玫瑰（Guns N' Roses）的波士顿演唱会
item.description:
终于一了夙愿，现场来到了枪炮与玫瑰的演唱会。记得小时候应城的堂哥带我去买他们的第一盘专辑磁带－Appetite for Destruction。堂哥描述这个乐队几乎“无恶不作“，追求“走调般的高音唱法“，但是“特别酷“。1988–1993, 一个摇滚史上再也不会重现的辉煌（Nirvana固然璀璨，但Cobain生前在演唱会上的成就和影响不能和Rose/Slash相比），枪炮与玫瑰成为glam rock最后的一个old school的传奇乐团。从那以后，美国本土被Nirvana的grunge和Smashing Pumpkins的alternative rock所占据，同时Oasis开始带领British Pop的侵略。新世纪伊始，乐坛则完全陷落在hip-hop的靡靡之音里。转眼十四年匆匆而过，和我一个时代的同龄人好多都根本没有听说过枪炮和玫瑰，让人不免唏嘘。

今天我应该感到很高兴，因为见到了Axl Rose。我们的座位离舞台只有十英尺。我和Rose最近时的距离就好比当年我在曼谷和张国荣（我至今很遗憾当时没去要个签名）邂逅时的远近。Rose还是活力十足，在舞台上不遗余力地左蹦右跳。几个经典动作跟当年一模一样。哎，衣不如新，人不如旧啊。他今天晚上没扎头巾，将一头长发束在脑后。一开始戴墨镜出场，后来扔掉了。略显沧桑之色，已不是在Sweet Child O’Mine里的那个像Johnny Depp的浪子了。

今天我应该感到很愤怒，因为Rose几乎迟到了三个半小时！大牌的演唱会我也去得不少了，不管是Suede, Prince, Oasis, Coldplay, 还是U2，一般都是让opening band预热一个小时左右然后登场。Oasis的闹腾了一个半小时，当时觉得很不爽。跟枪炮与玫瑰相比就是小巫了。两个opening band（Sebastian Bach和另外一个不知道名字的）各折腾了一个多小时。最要命的是每次换乐队的空隙里DCU Center的人都会把整个舞台重新布置一遍！第二天听地方电台说Rose十点钟还在纽约接受采访，几乎就回不来了。

今天我应该感到很高兴，因为我们没做火车来Worcester。我看演唱会是八点钟开始，就竟然一度天真地以为我们可以做火车来，然后赶午夜的最后一班回波士顿。Rose十一点半登场，唱足两个半小时。我们两点出会场，三点才开到家！到十一点左右的时候，我觉得场里的气氛越来越不对了－general admission里喝醉的人一个个地被保安拖出来；很多醉醺醺的大学生开始像野牛一样互相冲撞取乐，动则有人就真刀真枪地打得头破血流被保安架出去；很多装扮类似deadhead的大叔们蠢蠢欲动地好像准备要冲上舞台砸东西了。这个时候如果真的宣布show cancelled的话，火山会全面爆发，fight club即将成为血淋淋的事实。。。

今天我应该感到很遗憾，因为我实在没法分辨出Rose的声音。我觉得平心而论他今晚唱的水平是很高的，看得出非常投入。但我和衫阁嫒觉得大多数时候他的声音都淹没在乐器（Rose带了八个band member) 的惊涛骇浪中了。也许我听British Rock太多了，忘了glam rock／重金属本来就是这个样子的。听得出Rose的声音还是像以前那么激越高扬。他的声调如此之高，如此之尖细，听起来就像金属摩擦的声音一样，以至于我们只听得出最后拖尾的长音，调子什么的是绝对听不出来的了。唯一从头至尾听得清楚的是我们的最爱－Patience，多亏有前面那么一长段的清唱。相比之下，U2的演唱会尤显难得，Bono的嗓子绝对凌驾所有的乐器声和粉丝的尖叫声之上。

今天我应该感到很高兴，因为枪炮与玫瑰忠实地回顾了几乎所有大家都耳熟能详的经典。从Welcome to the Jungle开始，骚动不安的观众就像突然被点燃了一般，满眼皆是挥动的手臂和舞动的人群；Sweet Child O‘Mine开头的吉他riff一抬头大家就更疯狂了，尖叫声此起彼伏；到Live and Die时over-the-top的焰火把人们的肾上激素催发到了顶端；在演绎Bob Dylan的Knockin’ on Heaven’s Door时会场已成了一个超级karaoke; November Rain和Patience让我们觉得一切路上的磨难和等待都是值得的。最后他们在Night Train的高潮中结尾，曲终人散。

巧的是Placebo这天晚上同时在波士顿的一个bar里献唱。鱼肉熊掌不可兼得啊。

今后的目标: Depeche Mode，Metallica（估计六城转转是不会再陪我去了），Smashing Pumpkins，还有达明一派。

item.title: 好莱坞演技派四大天王
item.description:
如果要我来排一排好莱坞的四大天王的话，我的意见如下（排名分先后）。这里考虑的演员以主流派居多，不包括那些在个别电影里惊鸿一瞥的人(Philip Seymour Hoffman)。

骨灰代

Michael Caine (1933)

在他那个年代出来的人现在还能这么活蹦乱跳的实在是仅此一家。Caine已经拿了两个奥斯卡（六次提名），艺术上可以说没什么追求了。经常可以看到他和中生代演员的老中配（譬如和Cage这种半调子），随意在屏幕上演绎一把智者的形象，手到擒来。更难能可贵的是Caine的卖像相当出色（否则怎么够资格演绎1966年的原版Alfie呢），像Connery一样，越老越帅。

honorable considerations

Paul Newman 的实力举世公认，巅峰时人气直追Brando，但近年产量不多，不像Caine这么活跃。

老生代 （具体演技就不多说了，都是公认的）

Jack Nicholson (1937)

Nicholson 应该是这个超级俱乐部的老大。十二次提名，三次获奖。这么彪悍的战绩即使是DeNiro, Pacino Hoffman也只能忘尘莫及。Nicholson的戏路是四大天王里最广的一位。不管是正义侦探(Chinatown)，大恶奸雄(The Departed, A Few Good Men)，木讷会计（About Schmidt)，变态人魔（Batman), 癫狂疯汉(The Shining)，还是喜剧谐星(As Good As It Gets, Something’s Gotta Give)，样样都是超一流的身手。Nicholson另外一个出众的地方是他特别受大师级名导的青睐，譬如Polanski, Kubrick, Forman, Beatty, Scorsese (Batman的Burton属于visionary导演，离大师级还差了点），但并不依附于跟某个别导演的化学作用。

Robert De Niro (1943)

和Nicholson一样，忠奸皆能。最后一次提名是十五年前，这让De Niro和Nicholson拉开了些距离。六次提名里三次是拜Scorsese所赐，使他的演绎方式有点过于受Scorsese的影响。过去几年扩宽戏路成功地走出喜剧路线(Analyse This, Meet the Parents)，让人耳目一新。不过在拍非喜剧时De Niro已经走不出他自己以前的影子，不象Nicholson的形象里有一种说不出来的不确定因素。

Al Pacino (1940)

Pacino在Godfather系列里的演出（从纯情少男到坚忍勇决的教父）足以使他和任何演技派大腕一争雄长。作为四大天王里戏路最窄的一位，Pacino是屏幕上“passion”的化身。他所有的角色几乎都是passion某一方面的诠释，真的是把这种性情中人表达得淋漓尽致。这同时也给他带来单一化的毛病。虽然能演反派，但他的反派其实只是他的正派稍微转个身而已，从本质上并不会让观众恨之入骨（Scarface是多么强悍的偶像派啊）。

Dustin Hoffman (1937)  四大天王里的真正喜剧高手(Tootsie)，多种类型的角色都驾轻就熟，可惜长得太正，不能演反派。

honorable considerations:

Anthony Hopkins（Hopkins在圈内很受尊敬和拥戴，很多人选角色就因为有和Sir Hopkins同台入镜的机会。在整个九十年代傲视群雄－隔年就被提名一把。Hannibal固然让人不寒而栗，但未必能压过Nicholson, De Niro的屏幕效果。而且Hopkins虽然现在功成名就，但他在美国成名较晚。It all started with The Silence of the Lambs）, Ian McKellen (老戏骨，屏幕上巨有presence，气场超强。但除了LOTR和X-Men系列，并不被广大主流观众所熟识）, Morgan Freeman（老霉干菜越来越酷, 有型有款。Million Dollar Baby的那个奖其实是补偿当年让他饮恨的Driving Missy Daisy。）

中生代 （争论开始了。。。这四大天王的特性是票房号召力堪忧）

Kevin Spacey (1959)

这个级别里最让人有所期待的演员。Usual Suspect和American Beauty里的演出太惊艳了，Seven里的恶魔的恐惧值不亚于Dr. Hannibal。Spacey的脸没有很大特色，亦正亦邪，神色表情里有很多可以细细品味的地方。他拥有成为未来acting legend的很罕见的条件。

Tom Hanks (1956)

阿甘是很可爱的，百看不厌。我对Hanks并不感冒，但他这种成绩摆出来不上这个名单只怕不能服众。他扮演的不少角色都让我觉得不够让人信服(Dr.Robert Langdon, anyone?). 下巴上的肉可以割一割。鼻子不够挺，那是没救了。

Sean Penn (1960)

演技没话说，但个人性格问题让他不能很好地被主流观众所接受（不能产生角色替代感）。票房号召力近似于零。

Daniel Day-Lewis (1957)

优秀的演员，可是感觉上他生活在一个不一样的时代。长年近乎于隐居的生活使Lewis上这个榜相当勉强。五年以内很有可能被Owen和Clooney取代。

honorable considerations

Russell Crowe （有潜质，形象较单一，需要更多的时间来观察）, Robert Downey Jr（天才型选手，只要离毒品酒精远点，什么时候拿个小金人应该没问题）, Brad Pitt（在独立电影上的探索精神可嘉，不像Cruise那么在乎自己的容貌，很难得。看看Babel能不能让他奠立起演技派的形象）, Jonny Depp （最有个性的演员，也最难以预测。现在的主要兴趣爱好是Captain Jack Sparrow）, Clive Owen (1964)（我个人很喜欢，他需要时间和奖像来获得主流观众的认可）, George Clooney （外形和气质上最有味道，最像Gable, Steward, Grant, Peck那个时代的老明星的风范。现在这种人是稀有动物了）

新生代 （根据潜力股的角度来看）

Edward Norton (1969)

准备接Spacey的班吧.  平常人的look, 在角色上产生无限的遐想余地。

Christian Bale (1974)

从American Psyco到Batman Begins, Bale is back, but not quite yet。他需要更好的剧本和一个有化学作用的导演。马上去捧他的The Prestige的场。

Joaquin Pheonix (1974)

性格角色的广度上让人惊讶。什么叫charisma？看看Walk The Line就知道了。Norton和Bale是走复杂性格路线，Pheonix和Bana则都是超级leading man路线，“星味“写得满脸都是。

Eric Bana (1968)

要不是导演给Pitt设计的动作太帅，Bana几乎就出人意料地盖过了Pitt的Archilles。Bana的争议会比较大。

honorable considerations

Jude Law（太帅的卖像，过于性感的口音，略微限制了Law的发展，2004年的过度曝光差点葬送他的大好事业）, Ewan McGregor（水平永远都不会差，但感觉上升空间不多）。
